case_name: Income-tax Officer, 3rd Additional Business Circle, New Delhi v. M/s. Bharat Carbon Ribon Manufacturing Co.

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 106 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 106 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 13, 1962 of the Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated November 13, 1962 of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Income-tax Reference Case No. 3 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment and order in Income-tax Reference Case No. 3 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated November 13, 1962 of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Income-tax Reference Case No. 3 of 1959.

facts.text: The appeal is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Punjab at Chandigarh in a reference under s. 66(1) of the Income Tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Punjab at Chandigarh in a reference made to it under s. 66 1  of the Income Tax Act, 1922, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Assessment year 1947-48, accounting period calendar year ending 31st December 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The statement of case relates to the assessment year 1947-48, the accounting period being the calendar year ending 31st December, 1946.

facts.text: Assessee is a public limited company dealing in the manufacture and sale of stationery goods.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a public limited companypany dealing in the manufacture and sale of stationery goods.

facts.text: Before the partition of the Country the company's registered office as well as the head office was at Lahore.

anchor.surface_text: Before the partition of the Country the companypanys registered office as well as the head office was at Lahore.

facts.text: Pakistan Income-tax Officer completed assessment for 1947-48 on 28th January 1948 ignoring Avoidance of Double Taxation agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment for the year 1947-48 was companypleted by the Pakistan Income-tax Officer on the 28th January, 1948 companypletely ignoring the agreement of the Avoidance of Double Taxation of Income between the Pakistan and the Indian Governments.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer 3rd Additional Business Circle, New Delhi made assessment for 1947-48 on total income of Rs. 38,916.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment for the year 1947-48 was also made by the Income-tax Officer 3rd Additional Business Circle, New Delhi on a figure of Rs. 38,916.

facts.text: Assessee paid advance tax of Rs. 36,783/6/- under Section 18-A of Indian Income Tax Act between June 1946 and March 1947 to Income-tax Officer, Lahore.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the assessee had paid advance tax under Section 18-A of the Indian Income Tax Act to the tune of Rs. 36,783/6/- between June. 1946 and March, 1947. This tax was paid under the Indian Income-tax Act to the Income- tax Officer, Lahore.

facts.text: Payment of advance tax is common ground.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the assessee had paid advance tax under Section 18-A of the Indian Income Tax Act to the tune of Rs. 36,783/6/-

facts.text: Income-tax Officer III Additional Business Circle New Delhi by order dated March 1952 determined total income of assessee at Rs. 38,916 and directed demand notice.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer 111, Additional Business Circle, New Delhi, by his order, dated March. 1952, determined the total income of the respondent, M s. Bharat Carbon Ribon Manufac- turing Co., hereinafter to as the assessee at Rs. 38,916 and directed that demand numberice and chalan be issued.

facts.text: Assessee is M/s Bharat Carbon Ribbon Manufacturing Co.

anchor.surface_text: determined the total income of the respondent, M s. Bharat Carbon Ribon Manufac- turing Co., hereinafter to as the assessee at Rs. 38,916

facts.text: Assessee claimed before Appellate Assistant Commissioner credit for advance tax paid in Lahore under s.18A(11).

anchor.surface_text: Before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner one of the points taken up by the assessee was that credit should be given to him of the-advance tax paid by him in Lahore, under s. 18A  11  which reads as follows

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner disallowed the claim for credit.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner disallowed the claim.

facts.text: Pakistan ITO assessed on 28 January 1948 total income Rs.1,22,014 for income tax and Rs.52,780 for capital gains, total tax Rs.76,472/6/- .

anchor.surface_text: The same Income- tax Officer made an assessment for this very year on 28th January, 1948 on a total income of Rs. 1,22,014 for Income tax and Rs. 52,780 for capital gains. He worked out the total tax payable by the assessee at Rs. 76,472/6.

facts.text: Pakistan authorities set off advance tax of Rs.47,513 against Pakistan demand, balance Rs.20,000 due.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this assessment, even after setting off the tax paid under Section 18-A of Rs. 47,513 an amount of Rs. 20,000 was still due from this assessee. The amount under Section 18-A, has, therefore, been adjusted by the Pakistan authorities

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal allowed the assessee's claim for credit.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee filed an appeal before the Appellate Tribunal. The Tribunal allowed the claim on the ground that the language of s. 18A  11  was mandatory

facts.text: Tribunal directed refund to assessee out of advance tax paid in Lahore.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the order of the Tribunal directing a refund to the assessee out of the advance tax paid by him in Lahore is legal and valid ?

facts.text: At instance of Commissioner of Income Tax, reference made to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income Tax a refer- ence was made to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court answered both questions in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the High Court answered both the questions in the affirmative.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds assessee not entitled to adjustment of advance tax paid in Lahore against Indian demand for 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that the answer to the questions should be in the negative and against the assessee.

facts.text: Pakistan authorities adjusted the advance tax against their demand.

anchor.surface_text: Pakistan having made the adjustment, there was numbermoney left to be adjusted against the assessment in India.

facts.text: Advance tax paid under Indian IT Act before partition liable to adjustment in both India and Pakistan due to s.18(3) Indian Independence Act.

anchor.surface_text: in our opinion the effect of s. 18  3  of the Indian Independence Act was to change the incidents of the advance tax paid. Previously the advance tax was to be adjusted towards a single regular assessment to be made by British India.

facts.text: Dwarka Dass case is distinguishable as no regular assessments made in Pakistan there.

anchor.surface_text: Dwarka Dasss case 1  relied on by the learned companynsel for the assessee is distinguishable because that case proceeded on the assumption that numberregular assessments had been made in Pakistan for the relevant years

facts.text: Assessee paid advance tax to Income-tax Officer, Lahore.

anchor.surface_text: This tax was paid under the Indian Income-tax Act to the Income- tax Officer, Lahore.

facts.text: High Court observed Pakistan proceedings not under Indian IT Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, obvious that what may have been done by the Pakistan authorities in January, 1948, cannot be called a proceeding under the Indian Income Tax Act

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Tribunal after AAC.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee filed an appeal before the Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Indian Independence Act s.18(3) continued British India laws in both Dominions.

anchor.surface_text: under s. 18A 11  which reads as follows Any sum other than a penalty or interest paid by or recovered from an assessee in pursuance of the provisions of this section shall be treated as a payment of tax in respect of the income of the period which would be the previous year for an assessment for the financial year next following the year in which it was payable, and credit therefore shall be given to the assessee in the regular assessment.

concepts.interpretation: Due to s.18(3) of Indian Independence Act, incidents of advance tax changed post-partition; payable against two assessments (India and Pakistan); no credit available in India if already adjusted in Pakistan as no balance left.

issues.text: Whether the order of the Tribunal directing a refund to the assessee out of the advance tax paid by him in Lahore is legal and valid ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the order of the Tribunal directing a refund to the assessee out of the advance tax paid by him in Lahore is legal and valid ?

issues.text: Whether by virtue of s. 18 3 of the Indian Independence Act the advance tax paid by the assessee was liable to be adjusted against the assessments made both in Pakistan and in India

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, the learned counsel for the appellant, contends before us that by virtue of s. 18 3  of the Indian Independence Act, the Income Tax Act as it existed before the coming into force of the Indian Independence Act, applied both to the Dominion of Pakistan and the Dominion of India, and the result of this simultaneous application to both the Dominions was that the advance tax paid by the assessee was liable to be adjusted against the assessments made both in Pakistan and in India, and Pakistan having made the adjustment, there was no money left to be adjusted against the assessment in India.

holdings.text: The assessee is not entitled to adjustment of the advance tax paid under Section 18-A of the Indian Income-tax Act in Lahore against the demand of tax raised by the Income-tax Officer, New Delhi for 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the assesses was entitled to have an adjustment of the advance tax paid by it under Section 18-A of the Indian Income-tax Act in Lahore for the assessment year 1947-48 against the demand of tax raised by the Income-tax Officer 3rd Additional Business Circle, New Delhi for the assessment year 1947-48 ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Advance tax incidents altered by s.18(3) Indian Independence Act to be creditable against assessments in both India and Pakistan; Pakistan already adjusted it leaving no balance for India under s.18A(11).

holdings.text: The order of the Tribunal directing refund to the assessee out of advance tax paid in Lahore is not legal and valid.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the order of the Tribunal directing a refund to the assessee out of the advance tax paid by him in Lahore is legal and valid ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Depends on first question; no entitlement to credit hence no basis for refund.

holdings.text: By virtue of s.18(3) of the Indian Independence Act, the advance tax paid was liable to adjustment against assessments in both Pakistan and India; effect changed incidents from single British India assessment to two dominion assessments.

anchor.surface_text: in our opinion the effect of s. 18  3  of the Indian Independence Act was to change the incidents of the advance tax paid. Previously the advance tax was to be adjusted towards a single regular assessment to be made by British India. After the Indian Independence Act the advance tax was liable to be adjusted against two regular assessments, one by India and one by Pakistan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18(3) continued British India laws including IT Act in both dominions with adaptations; advance tax not doubled but same amount creditable in both places; Pakistan entitled to adjust under s.18A(11) as was India.

holdings.text: If assessee given credit for advance tax by Pakistan, cannot claim credit from Indian Income Tax authorities as no amount left on which s.18A(11) could operate.

anchor.surface_text: Having been given credit by the Pakistan Government he companyld number claim that there was any amount left on which s. 18  A 11 companyld operate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-partition, advance tax adjusted in Pakistan against its regular assessment; balance zero for India.

holdings.text: Dwarka Dass case is distinguishable as no regular assessments made in Pakistan there unlike here where Pakistan made regular assessment and adjusted advance tax.

anchor.surface_text: Dwarka Dasss case 1  relied on by the learned companynsel for the assessee is distinguishable because that case proceeded on the assumption that numberregular assessments had been made in Pakistan for the relevant years

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different facts: no Pakistan regular assessment or adjustment in that case.

holdings.text: Not necessary to consider interpretation of s.9 Indian Independence (Rights, Property and Liabilities) Order, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: In this view it is not necessary to consider the interpretation of s. 9 of the Indian Independence  Rights, Property and Liabilities  Order, 1947.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue resolved by effect of simultaneous IT Act application in both dominions via s.18(3) IIA.

holdings.text: Answers to the referred questions are in the negative and against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that the answer to the questions should be in the negative and against the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Summarising holdings on entitlement to credit and validity of Tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: in our opinion the effect of s. 18  3  of the Indian Independence Act was to change the incidents of the advance tax paid. Previously the advance tax was to be adjusted towards a single regular assessment to be made by British India. After the Indian Independence Act the advance tax was liable to be adjusted against two regular assessments, one by India and one by Pakistan.
In the result we hold that the answer to the questions should be in the negative and against the assessee.
